skill.name: c4-architecture
skill.description: Generate architecture documentation using C4 model Mermaid diagrams. Use when asked to create architecture diagrams, document system architecture, visualize software structure, create C4 diagrams, or generate context/container/component/deployment diagrams. Triggers include "architecture diagram", "C4 diagram", "system context", "container diagram", "component diagram", "deployment diagram", "document architecture", "visualize architecture".
skill.summary: Generate professional C4 architecture diagrams in Mermaid syntax for documentation and visualization.
skill.author: softaworks

security_audit.summary: Static analysis detected 388 pattern matches, but all are false positives. The 'external_commands' and 'network' patterns match Mermaid diagram syntax (e.g., Person(), Container()) and documentation URLs, not actual code execution. This is a pure documentation skill with no scripts, no executable code, and no security risks.

content.value_statement: Communicate software architecture clearly with professional C4 model diagrams. This skill generates Mermaid-based documentation at the right abstraction level for any audience, from executives to developers.
actual_capabilities: Generate C4 Context diagrams showing system scope and external actors
Create Container diagrams displaying apps, databases, and services
Build Component diagrams for internal code structure
Produce Deployment diagrams for infrastructure visualization
Design Dynamic diagrams showing request flows with numbered steps
Adapt diagram detail level based on target audience
limitations: Generates Mermaid syntax only, does not render images directly
Requires understanding of the codebase to create accurate diagrams
Complex systems may need multiple diagrams to remain readable
Cannot automatically discover architecture without code analysis

use_cases.title: Document Existing Systems
use_cases.description: Software teams use this skill to create architecture documentation for legacy systems. The skill analyzes code structure and generates diagrams that help onboard new developers.

use_cases.title: Design Review Presentations
use_cases.description: Technical leads generate audience-appropriate diagrams for design reviews. Context diagrams for executives, container diagrams for technical stakeholders.

use_cases.title: Microservices Documentation
use_cases.description: Teams document complex microservices architectures with proper boundaries and relationships. The skill handles event-driven patterns and inter-service communication.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Architecture Overview
prompt_templates.prompt: Create architecture diagrams for my [project name]. Include a system context diagram and a container diagram.

prompt_templates.title: Document Microservices
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate C4 diagrams for our microservices architecture. We have [list services] that communicate via [message broker/API]. Create container diagrams showing each service with its database.

prompt_templates.title: Show Request Flow
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a dynamic diagram showing the [feature name] flow. Number the steps from user action through all services involved.

prompt_templates.title: Production Deployment
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a deployment diagram for our [AWS/Azure/GCP] infrastructure. Show the regions, clusters, and how services are deployed.

best_practices: Always start with Level 1 Context diagrams to establish system scope before diving into containers
Keep diagrams under 20 elements by splitting complex systems into multiple focused diagrams
Label relationships with action verbs and technology (e.g., "Reads from", "JSON/HTTPS")
anti_patterns: Do not use bidirectional arrows - they create ambiguity about data flow direction
Avoid modeling shared libraries as containers - containers must be deployable units
Do not skip the Context diagram - it is essential for non-technical stakeholders

faq.question: What is the C4 model?
faq.answer: The C4 model is a simple visual language for describing software architecture. It has four levels: Context (system scope), Container (deployable units), Component (internal structure), and Code (implementation details). Most teams only need the first two levels.

faq.question: How do I view the generated diagrams?
faq.answer: The skill generates Mermaid syntax in markdown files. You can view these in any tool that supports Mermaid: GitHub, GitLab, VS Code with extensions, or the Mermaid Live Editor online.

faq.question: Which diagram level should I use?
faq.answer: Use Context diagrams for executives and non-technical stakeholders. Use Container diagrams for technical teams. Component diagrams are only needed when internal structure adds value. Deployment diagrams are for DevOps and infrastructure discussions.

faq.question: Can I customize the diagram styling?
faq.answer: Yes. The skill supports Mermaid C4 styling functions like UpdateElementStyle and UpdateRelStyle. You can customize colors, fonts, and relationship offsets to improve readability.

faq.question: How do I document microservices?
faq.answer: For single-team ownership, model microservices as containers within a system boundary. For multi-team ownership, promote each microservice to a system in the Context diagram. Always show databases and message queues as separate containers.

faq.question: What is a Dynamic diagram?
faq.answer: Dynamic diagrams show runtime behavior with numbered steps. Use them to document request flows, transaction processing, or event propagation through your system. They help explain complex interactions that static diagrams cannot capture.
